body:
### Speech.Synthesis.SpeechSynthesizer Broken in CORE

RE-OPENED [8809](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/8809)

## Steps to reproduce

```
Add-Type -AssemblyName System.speech
$speak = New-Object System.Speech.Synthesis.SpeechSynthesizer
$speak.Speak("test");

```

## Expected behavior

```
hear "test" from speakers, just like in PS 5.1

```

## Actual behavior

```
Exception calling "Speak" with "1" argument(s): "Object reference not set to an instance of an object."

```

## Environment data


POWERSHELL 5
```
PSVersion                      5.1.17134.407
PSEdition                      Desktop
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
BuildVersion                   10.0.17134.407
CLRVersion                     4.0.30319.42000
WSManStackVersion              3.0
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1

```

POWERSHELL CORE 7.1.3
```
Name                           Value
----                           -----

PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.1.3
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19042
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0

```

comments.body:
There is not `System.speech` in Net 5, but I cannot understand why no errors when `Add-Type -assembly System.Speech`
```powershell
 > using assembly System.Speech
ParserError:
Line |
   1 |  using assembly System.Speech
     |                 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~
     | Cannot load assembly 'System.Speech'.
```

You can use Sapi:
```
$sp = New-Object -ComObject Sapi.SpVoice
[void] $sp.Speak('text')

$sp | Get-Member  # for settings
```

comments.author: SeeminglyScience
comments.body: There's nothing PowerShell can do about this.  That library took a dependency on the name of a private field (`RegistryKey.hkey`, now renamed to `_hkey`) and that's why it's throwing.  Until that assembly (which is not part of this repo) is updated, you'll need to find an alternative API.

comments.author: ghost
comments.body:
To close this matter.; On Powershell Core, **_New-Object System.Speech.Synthesis.SpeechSynthesizer_** fails.
```
$David=New-Object System.Speech.Synthesis.SpeechSynthesizer
$David.SelectVoice('Microsoft David Desktop')
$David.Speak($Statement)
```

But **_New-Object -ComObject Sapi.SpVoice_** WORKS
```
$sp = New-Object -ComObject Sapi.SpVoice
[void] $sp.Speak('text')
```

I don't know if the fact that System.Speech.Synthesis.SpeechSynthesizer isn't supported in PWSH 7 is a bug, but my problem is fixed in that I circumvented the issue by using Sapi.SpVoice.

Thanks!
